History:
History: The royal family is of the Yao tribe. Their ancestors came from Mangochi district in the 1800s. They were led by Chalamanda, Chiimire Matola and Zinganguwo. From Mangochi they went to namulenga in Chiradzulu where they also moved to Chilomoni in Blantyre near Sigelege at a place called Chigwacha.

Due to internal disagreements, the tribe was divided into three groups. The other group was lef t at Chigwacha while the other two groups went to Mulanje district and Chiimire settled with his followers at Nancholi. Mary Daudi, the current Village Headwoman Chiimire was enthroned in the year 2005. In year 2005 Chiimire was just a Village Headperson (VH) but because of the number of development activities that the chief had been spearheading the Malawi government decided to elevate the chief taincy from VH to GVH. GVH Chiimire has four VH that assist her in running the community. The chiefs are Baluti, Nkoka, Sumani and Manyenje.
Priorities: Waterdrainage, Sanitationsewage, Housing, Electricity, Waterdrainage, Sanitationsewage, Housing, Electricity
Facilities: Playground, Generalshops, Informalmarkets, Foodshops, Furnitureshops, Churches, Carrepair

History:
History: Manase is an informal settlement within Blantyre City located about 10 kilometres in the Southern part of the district.
The settlement began in the early 1900’s when the Yao people were re-located by the government from their original area Matenje, present day Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital (QECH).

Although, the area has people from different ethnic groups, the Yaos were the first people to settle there; hence, the settlement is characterised by two main Yao traditional dances of Beni and Manganje and Likwata The chief taincy is passed on to either male or female members within the loyal family.

The current GVH Sumani is the fourth and was enthroned in 1998. GVH Sumani has two counselors, Tambala and Kalambo, who assist her in running day-to-day af fairs in the community.
Priorities: N/A

History:
History: Chinsapo Township is in Area 57 and ex tends to Area 58 within Lilongwe City. It lies six kilometres northwest of Lilongwe City Centre. It is one of the most well known informal settlements in the City of Lilongwe. It started as a village some decades ago before Lilongwe was declared a Capital city. The early settlers in the area had their village along Lilongwe and Chankhandwe rivers. The settlement is led by Group Village Headman Chinsapo.

According to some legend in the township,the settlement’s name originates from misspelling and mispronunciation. It is said that the area around Chinsapo had so many pythons and these long snakes are called nsato in Chewa language. Chinsato means a huge python.
So this area was therefore called Chinsato because of the abundant pythons. Out of Chinsato came Chinsapo, perhaps ending the pythonic era. But some elders in the area say the name came with their ancestors from the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).

Facilities: Playground, Policestations, Informalmarkets, Temples, Mosques, Churches

History:
History: The indigenous people of Mtsiliza migrated from Mbizi which is the present day Area 9. The indigenous people are of the Chewa
tribe who are known to have migrated from the present day Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) sometime back.

Their local language is Chewa and they are characterised by their trademark traditional dance known as Gule Wamkulu. These ancestors willingly migrated from Mbizi to Mtsiliza without any eviction.

Mbizi was a stopover station as most chiefs who settled there migrated on to their present settlements though the exact year was neither documented nor is it remembered. Notable chiefs who rested at Mbizi on their way were Dule, Njewa, Muzu and Mtsiliza.
Since migration from Mbizi, the current GVH Mtsiliza is the third on the throne. The second Mtsiliza came to power in the year 1956 and passed away in the year 1988. The current Chief Mtsiliza was enthroned in the year 1990.
Priorities: Housing, Sanitationsewage, Waterdrainage, Electricity, Landtenure, Housing, Sanitationsewage, Waterdrainage, Electricity, Landtenure
Facilities: Playground, Informalmarkets, Furnitureshops, Temples, Mosques, Churches

History:
History: The first people who settled in Mgona arrived in the year 1982. These early settlers were evictees of Thope-Maula—where Maula Prison is currently located. The people were evicted from their original homes to pave way for government’s plans of constructing a prison service in the location.

After the eviction from Thope-Maula, they settled in an Area called Maria, present day Area 49. But due to internal conflicts or disagreements, some members seceded and settled at Mgona. Reasons for the secession and relocation to Mgona were rather tactical. The people wanted to be strategically positioned considering the ‘industrial revolution’ that was booming in the area at the time.

History: History: The first people to settle in the community came in the year 1910. Th e s e p e o p l e originated from Kachipapa in Ntchisi district. They first established at Chankhungu before moving to Lilongwe. After migrating to Lilongwe, they first asked for settlement land in the area of Group Village Headman (GVH) Chimoka. The Ngomani area was given to them by the GVH Chimoka. Mainly, they left their original district of Ntchisi because itsmountainous terrainmade their access to water difficult and the threats of wild animals risked their safety. Further, Ngomani had good farming land,employment opportunities as well as business opportunities.

History:
History: Were the Amang’anja. The Yao came and fought the Amang’anja in the 1800. These Yao people emigrated from an
area called Yao in Mozambique. After their defeat at Chigumula-Mtambo, the Amang’anja lef t the area and migrated to Thyolo and Chiradzulu districts. These are neighboring districts to Blantyre.

The Yao tribe lef t Mozambique to Malawi due to poor governance and authoritarian rule by the colonial Portuguese
government. The Yao groups that settled in Blantyre were led by their chiefs, Kapeni and Nsomba.

Other chiefs started flocking to the occupied area, asking for land to settle on with their subjects from the chiefs they had found, namely Kapeni and Nsomba. The chiefs who came to settle in the area were of Yao, Lhomwe, Ngoni and Amang’anja tribes.

Today, all existing Malawian tribes are found in the settlement because the area is within the city.
Priorities: N/A
